node.title: Respecting Food
node.label: 11. September 2020
node.introduction: Have you ever thought about the meals you eat and given them a respect ranking? What does this even mean?

node.title: Top Tips for Picky Eaters
node.label: 10. September 2020
node.introduction: Some people just don't like a lot of food or let's just say, they like what they like and that's all there is to it!

node.title: Creamy Smoked Mackerel Pate
node.introduction: Mackerel is a good source of protein and is high in omega three. Serve with vegetable sticks to count towards your five a day.

node.title: Chocolate, Orange, Coco-nutty Clusters
node.introduction: Dark chocolate can stimulate the production of endorphins. This is because it contains tryptophan, an amino acid that is a precursor to the feel good hormone; serotonin. It can make us feel happy, create feelings of pleasure, as well as reduce pain.

node.title: Sweetcorn Pancakes & Tomato Salsa
node.introduction: Sometimes you just need a little change from the usual pancakes. This is where these savoury Mexican inspired pancakes come into their own. Served with the salsa and a nice home made guacamole you can't really go wrong. Best of all you can pack in 2 or 3 portions of veg and kids love them too.

node.text:
Menopause starts in your 30's. YES IT REALLY DOES! 
Well actually Perimenopause - is when we experience a lot of the most common symptoms. Some ladies start at age 35 but most commonly it's early to mid 40’s. It can last between 2 -12 years but the average is 7 years. 

Stage 1 - The very early stage, cycles are still regular but may start to shorten. Regular 28 day cycles may become 26 days. You might experience common symptoms like night sweats, headaches and sleep disturbances. 

STAGE 2 - Early menopause transition onset of irregular periods. This can feel a bit like you are coming and going. Long periods, short periods, heavy, light. You just finish and 10 days later you can be bleeding again. Brain fog, anxiety and energy dips start to kick in!

STAGE 3 - Late menopause translation from the first cycle of more than 60 days. Things can start to get a little interesting. You might experience a few 60-80 day day gaps then it could be 5 or 6 months. It’s a good idea to carry an SOS pack (tampons, pads, spare knickers) in your bag. Everything seems to be coming at you: weight gain, low energy, mood swings, hot flushes, night time waking. The brain fog and anxiety can really ramp up. 

STAGE 4. Late menopause, 12 months from the final period. Some ladies call this the waiting room. It can be 10 or 11 months and then BOOM out of nowhere you get a period. Back to square one and the waiting starts again. This usually only happens once if at all. 
VOILA…….Menopause - 1 day to achieve, one year after your final period. The life phase that everyone is waiting for. 

1, 2, 3 or 4, WHICH PHASE ARE YOU IN? tell me in the comments 👇

Stop ignoring your inner voice and start putting yourself first. 

The last few weeks have been a bit of a roller coaster. I've taken my eye off the ball when it comes to my health and now I'm paying the price.

I'm not talking about massive changes but just being mindful of a few basic things that make a big difference to the way you feel. 

Lowering the stress on your body is one of the MOST important things you can do in perimenopause. It helps to reduce symptoms especially anxiety. 

Here's 3 things YOU could be doing that's making your anxiety sky rocket!

1. No proper sleep routine
2. Relying on caffeine
3. No work life balance

1, 2 or 3 what one having you been letting slide this week? Tell me in the comments 👇

See how easily you can Banish Brain fog with these 5 simple steps. 

I had an interesting conversation with my friend Sarah this week. We were out walking our dogs and whilst hiding under a tree from the rain, she suddenly pulled out her pill box and said; 'oh no I forgot to take my pills'. 

I asked her why she didn't have a reminder on her phone. 

She told me she did but … technology is only as good as the person receiving it!
Her phone had gone off to remind her to take her pills.  But as she went into the kitchen to grab a glass of water … she totally forgot why she went there in the first place. 
 
So .. she just grabbed her coat and the dog and came to meet me! 

This got us chatting about how annoying and sometimes detrimental (she has to take her pills within a 30 minute time slot) to our health brain fog is. Just the sheer unpredictability of it and not knowing when it could strike is the worst part. 

In perimenopause your body and brain is under a huge amount of stress. The loss of oestrogen and progesterone can result in many symptoms including disrupted sleep, anxiety and brain fog.

Why? 

Because oestrogen helps your brain cells to use glucose for energy. When you move to the lower oestrogen state of menopause your brain can have as much as a 25% drop in energy and brain activity. 

Scary stuff right? 

But the good news is, there are ways you can support your brain and body during perimenopause.

That’s why I’ve created 5 Steps to Banish Brain fog so you can Think Straight actionable workbook. 
Inside you’ll:
✔️Discover The No 1 way to get more mental clarity with just one dietary addition.
✔️Find out the right amount of protein to keep you energised and thinking straight all day.
✔️Learn simple ways to soothe your nervous system so you feel less stressed and fuzzy headed.
✔️How to keep your memory sharp and your mood more even with easy hydration hacks.

The steps you'll find inside the Banish your Brain Fog Workbook follow the process that I teach my 1:1 clients to help them ditch the brain fog and finally start feeling normal again. 
Grab your free copy by clicking on the link in my bio 

Emma x

metadata.siteDescription: ENERGISE, RESTORE, NOURISH. I'm studying with the renowned Institute for Optimum Nutrition and will qualify next year. Until then, this is a place to inspire and share healthful information, tips, tricks and recipes. I hope to energise, restore and nourish your body mind and soul!
